title: Ashcroft & Mermin in 60 Days
text:
A tweet inspired journey to digest all of the iconic Ashcroft & Mermin in 60 days. The goal is to read about 13 pages everyday, take notes1, and discuss. Lets go!
1 These will be more of dictations rather than rephrasings. The intent is to capture the most important content.


Seems like people like the book club idea! The first book will be solid state physics (ashcroft/mermin), I'll set up a space for next thursday to talk about chs. 1-4 (p. 1-84 in my edition). Like or DM if you want to join, I'll create a groupchat. https://t.co/QNrgHAsb6O

— Max Aifer (@MaxAifer) June 7, 2024



Max Aifer is also providing his Notion notes.

title: Drude Theory (pp. 14-26)
text:
When a time varying electric field is present, \(\mathbf{E}(t) = Re\left(\mathbf{E}(\omega)e^{-i\omega t}\right)\), the frequency dependent electrical conductivity is:
\[ \sigma(\omega) = \frac{\sigma_o}{1-i\omega t}\]
with \(\sigma_o\) being the DC Drude conductivity. If we look to solutions for to Maxwell’s equations given a specified current density \(\mathbf{j}\), the resulting wave equation has dielectric constant of the form:
\[\mathbf{\epsilon}(\omega) = 1 + \frac{4\pi i \sigma}{\omega}\].
Assuming \(\omega \tau \gg 1\) and thus \(1-i\omega\tau \approx -i\omega \tau\), then:
\[\mathbf{\epsilon}(\omega) = 1 - \frac{3\pi n e^2}{m \omega^2} = 1 - \frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2} \tag{1}\]
where \(\omega_p^2\) is called the plasma frequency and dictates wheter EM radiation can propagate through the electron gas. Another outcome from Equation 1, is charge density oscillations that have oscillatory time depencence \(e^{-i\omega t}\).

title: Drude Theory (pp. 14-26)
text:
Thermal Conductivity of a Metal
A one-dimensonal thermal current will be given by \(j^q = -\kappa \frac{dT}{dx}\). Simplifying this to view the thermal energy per electron before and after a collision, would be \(\mathcal{E}(T[x\prime])\) and \(\mathcal{E}(T[x])\), respectively. Consider that two thermal resivoirs, a hot and cold, then we can write:
\[ j^q = \frac{1}{2} n\, v\left( \mathcal{E}(T[x-v\tau]) - \mathcal{E}(T[x+v\tau])\right) \]
the first term in parenthesis is the hot and the second the cold. The prefactor is the number of electrons and their velocity. Expanding about the point \(x\) gives:
\[j^q = nv^2\tau \frac{d\mathcal{E}}{dT}\left(-\frac{dT}{dx}\right)\]
In 3D, assumping isotropic velocity distribution, \(\langle \mathbf{v} \rangle = \frac{1}{3}v^2\), and from thermodynamics \(n\frac{\mathcal{E}}{dT}=C_v\). Then the thermal current is given as:
\[\mathbf{j}^q = -\frac{1}{3}v^2\tau C_v \nabla T\]
and defining thermal conductivity as:
\[ \frac{1}{3} v^2 \tau C_v \]
One of the success of this analysis is the Wiedemann-Franz law, which assumes both the electronic specific heat, \(C_v\), and the electronic velocity \(v\) are described through classical ideal gas laws and thus leads to:
\[\frac{\kappa}{\sigma} = \frac{3}{2} \left(\frac{k_B}{e}\right)^2 T\,,\]
Which surprisingly agreed with experiments, because the electronic contributions to specific heat is no where near \(\frac{3}{2} n k_B\). It turned out that the agreement was pure luck in canceling of two errors in the Drude theory approximation that cancel each other out.

title: Drude Theory (pp. 14-26)
text:
Thermopower
Similar to thermal conductivity, using the Drude theory to analyze thermopower in thermoelectrics, it is found to be constant:
\[ Q = -\frac{k_B}{2e} \]

title: Drude Theory (pp. 1-13)
text:
The Drude theory is a basic model treating the conductive electrons under kinetic theory. The ion core, \(eZ_a\) and core electrons, \(e\left(Z_a-Z\right)\), are treated as stationary. Only interactions between conduction electrons and the core electrons and ion are considered.
Give such treatment, the electron density in number of electrons per \(\text{cm}^3\) is written as:
\[n = 6.022 \times 10^{23} \frac{Z_c\rho_m}{A}\]
with \(Z_c\) the number of conduction electrons contributed by an atom and \(\rho_m\) and \(A\) are the mass density and atomic mass, respectively.
A effective electron radius can be defined by considering a conduction volume of a sphere, \(r_s = (\frac{3}{4\pi n})^{1/3}\).
The Drude model assumes only interactions between effective ion cores and independent electrons. We write a collision frequency for electron-ion as \(\frac{1}{\tau}\).

title: Drude Theory (pp. 1-13)
text:
DC Electrical Conductivity
The resistance, \(R\), is a dimension dependent quantity and can be removed by considering the resistivity, \(rho\), a takes meaning when defining the electric field at a point due to a current density.:
\[\mathbf{E} = \rho \mathbf{j}\]
In the Drude model \(\mathbf{j}\) can be expressed in terms of charge density and average velocity, \(\mathbf{v}\)
\[\mathbf{j} = -e\,n\mathbf{v}\].
The average velocity of an electron in the presence of a field can be approximated as \(\mathbf{v} = \frac{e\mathbf{E}\tau}{m_e}\), \(m_e\) being the mass of an electron.
Putting it together in terms of currenty density \(j\):
\[\mathbf{j} = \sigma \mathbf{E} = \frac{ne^2 \tau}{m_e} \mathbf{E}\]
with \(\sigma\) being the conductivity. Measuring \(\sigma\) (or \(\rho\)) enables determining \(\tau\) which ranges from 1-10 femtoseconds. The mean free path then being \(\lambda=v_o \tau\).
If assuming equipartion of energy for a free gas, then \(v_o = \frac{3}{2}k_b T\) and \(\lambda\) is between 1-10 Angstroms.
The electron current density can be written in terms of momentum and the effect of an external field and collisions, \(\frac{dt}{\tau}\), can be included. Without collisions, \((1-\frac{dt}{\tau})\), the momentum, \(p(t+dt)\) is given as:
\[ \mathbf{p}(t+dt)= \mathbf{p}(t) - \left(\frac{dt}{\tau}\right)\mathbf{p}(t) + \mathbf{f}(t) dt + \mathcal{O}(dt)^2 \]
The collision term, \(\frac{dt}{\tau}\), only affects terms of \(\mathcal{O}(dt)^2\). Then, rearranging, dividing by \(dt\), and taking limit as \(dt \rightarrow 0\), gives:
\[
\frac{d\mathbf{p}(t)}{dt} = -\frac{\mathbf{p}(t)}{\tau} + \mathbf{f}(t)
\tag{1}\]
This states that individual collisions of electrons introduce a frictiaonal damping1
1 Max mentioned in our twitter dicussion that this looks very similar to fluctuation-dissipation theorems in thermodynamics.

title: Drude Theory (pp. 1-13)
text:
Hall Effect, Magnetoresistance
The Drude theory can be used to solve the following setup:



Hall experiment


A magnetoresistance is experienced due to the force felt on the current,\(j_x\), along a substrate. A Hall coefficient can be defined as \(R_H = \frac{E_y}{j_x H}\).
If we find steady-state solutions for \(j_x\) using the Equation 1, one gets:
\[
\begin{align}
\sigma_o E_x  &= \omega_c \tau j_y + j_x \\
\sigma_o E_y &= -\omega_c \tau j_x + j_y \\
\end{align}
\],
but there is no transverse current \(j_y\) when the Hall field \(E_y\) is present. Therefore, the hall resistance is given by:
\[ R_H = -\frac{1}{nec} \]

title: Ch. 1-4
text:
Transcript Summary

General Reading Experience

Participants found the material dense and challenging.
Some participants were familiar with the core concepts, but not all technical details.



Chapter 1: Drude Model

Introduction to the Drude Model

The model applies the kinetic theory of gases to electrons in metals.
Initial simplicity evolves into more sophisticated models as constraints are added.

Assumptions of the Drude Model

Basic assumptions about electron collisions, probability, and velocity.
Simplified by ignoring electron-electron interactions.

DC Electrical Conductivity

Ohm’s law derived from the Drude model.
Electrical conductivity depends on the number density of electrons (n) and the average collision time (tau).

Hall Effect

Used to differentiate between positive and negative charge carriers.
Hall coefficient (R_H) indicates the type of charge carrier and its density.

AC Conductivity

Metals become transparent above a certain frequency (plasma frequency).
Conductivity decreases with increasing frequency due to fewer electron collisions.

Thermal Conductivity

Relation between thermal and electrical conductivity (Wiedemann-Franz law).
Thermal conductivity also influenced by electron collisions.

Thermoelectric Effect

Prediction that certain parameters are constants, unaffected by electron density.




Chapter 2: Sommerfeld Model

Introduction to the Sommerfeld Model

Modifies the Drude model by incorporating quantum mechanics.
Electrons follow Fermi-Dirac statistics instead of Maxwell-Boltzmann.

Fermi-Dirac Distribution

Describes the probability of electron occupancy at various energy levels.
Key feature: Sharp drop-off at the Fermi level that broadens with increasing temperature.

Electron Velocity Distribution

Higher average electron velocities compared to the Drude model due to quantum effects.
Velocity distribution is discrete rather than continuous.

Thermal Properties

Explains how electronic heat capacity affects thermal conductivity.
Fermi level’s stability over temperature changes impacts thermal properties.




Quantum Mechanical Intuition

Discussion on teaching methodologies:

Classical mechanics provides foundational intuition.
Gradually introducing quantum concepts adds depth to understanding.

Importance of combining classical and quantum perspectives for comprehensive learning.



Practical Applications

Hall Effect Sensors

Widely used in microelectronics and position sensing.
Libraries available for integrating Hall Effect sensors with microcontrollers like Arduino.




Additional Comments

Exploring the future of physics education with quantum intuition.
Potential of neural networks in discovering new physical equations.
Relation between classical models and emerging quantum effects in materials science.
